BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger. Dry loose snow avalanches are still possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from northwesterly directions, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last two days especially above approximately 2100 m.
The near-surface layers of the snowpack can be released in some places by individual winter sport participants in particular on wind-loaded slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and in pass areas. At intermediate and high altitudes these avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
Avalanches can in isolated cases reach quite a large size in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.

On extremely steep slopes and on wind-loaded slopes more loose snow avalanches are possible. Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised as well in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
50 to 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last few days above approximately 2100 m. In the last two days the wind was strong in some localities.
The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly at elevated altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Over a wide area various wind slab layers are lying on a hard crust. In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually. The weather conditions will foster a stabilisation of the near-surface layers.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the strong westerly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed during the last few days. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above approximately 2200 m. The wind slabs have formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Caution is to be exercised at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. The avalanches can reach large size. The avalanche prone locations are prevalent and are difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Monday above approximately 1800 m. The strong wind has transported a lot of snow. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs represent the main danger.
Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above the tree line. Large and, in isolated cases, very large natural avalanches are possible.
The fresh snow as well as the often deep wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow and wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from westerly directions, sometimes deep wind slabs formed in the last two days.
The near-surface layers of the snowpack can be released in some places by individual winter sport participants on wind-loaded slopes. Avalanches can and reach medium size.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above the tree line. At intermediate and high altitudes these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.

On extremely steep slopes more dry loose snow avalanches are possible as the day progresses.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last few days above approximately 2100 m.
Thus far the wind has been strong in some localities. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly at elevated altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of new snow and a moderate wind, wind slabs formed in the last two days in all aspects. The new snow can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above the tree line. The off-piste conditions are dangerous.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 30 cm of snow, and up to 40 cm in some localities, fell in the last two days above approximately 1800 m. Over a wide area new snow is lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack. Distinct weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack are difficult to recognise. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted and weak. Avalanches can be released in near-surface layers very easily.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads,.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow and wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from westerly directions, mostly small wind slabs formed.
The fresh and older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable) the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. Above the tree line the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.

In particular on extreme slopes and in steep rocky terrain mostly small natural avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
5 to 15 cm of snow fell in the last few days above approximately 2100 m. The wind was strong in some localities. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Especially on steep sunny slopes as well as below approximately 1900 m only a little snow is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads,.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1500 m only a little snow is lying. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind, mostly small wind slabs formed in the last few days at elevated altitudes. The fresh wind slabs can be released in some cases in particular on north to northeast to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2400 m. The more recent wind slabs are to be bypassed in very steep terrain. As a consequence of falling temperatures, the natural avalanche activity will appreciably decrease.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack is largely stable and its surface has a crust that is strong in many cases. This applies in particular below approximately 2400 m.
In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow represent the main danger. Along the border with France a considerable danger of dry avalanches will be encountered in some localities.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in the last few days. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2400 m. More recent wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. They can be released easily in particular on north to northeast to east facing aspects above approximately 2400 m, especially at their margins. The meteorological conditions will facilitate a substantial strengthening of the near-surface layers in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. As the temperature drops hardly any more moist and wet avalanches are to be expected. In many places there is a danger of falling on the hard crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of a strong wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last few days in particular along the border with France. Stability tests and field observations have shown poor snowpack stability on steep shady slopes. Weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack here. As a consequence of low temperatures a crust will form on the surface.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant on northeast to north to northwest facing aspects above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs can still in isolated cases be released by small loads and reach medium size. Careful route selection and spacing between individuals are recommended.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The more recent wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Some fresh snow and in particular the sometimes deep wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects and above the tree line. The fresh wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack. These can be released easily by a single winter sport participant. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in all aspects. The sometimes large wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. They are to be avoided whenever possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 1500 m. More recent wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack above the tree line. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are in some cases prone to triggering.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
More recent wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases above approximately 2200 m. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2200 m, especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. They are to be avoided as far as possible. Mostly avalanches are only small. Even a small avalanche can sweep winter sport participants along and give rise to falls.

On extremely steep sunny slopes individual small dry loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of solar radiation.
In addition still more very occasional gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m, in particular in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The conditions are wintry. Up to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Wednesday. The wind has transported the new snow. The fresh wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack. They are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack especially on steep shady slopes.

Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. This is particularly the case in the areas with less snow, well off the main Alpine ridge. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations above the tree line.

Low and intermediate altitudes: Towards its base, the snowpack is moist; its surface consists of loosely bonded snow.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The wind slabs remain in some cases prone to triggering especially on very steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow represent the main danger. Along the border with France the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last few days. They can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on north to northeast to east facing aspects above approximately 2400 m, especially at their margins. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. The meteorological conditions will facilitate a rapid strengthening of the near-surface layers in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. As the temperature drops hardly any more moist and wet avalanches are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 15 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Monday above approximately 1800 m. Up to 1900 m rain has fallen. The strong wind has transported the new snow. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack on steep shady slopes. In particular slopes low and intermediate altitudes: As a consequence of low temperatures a crust will form on the surface.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The more recent wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs of the last few days are poorly bonded with the old snowpack. The fresh wind slabs can be released easily. or in isolated cases naturally,.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The wind slabs represent the main danger. The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be good. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will hardly soften at all.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will become generally well bonded.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area up to 5 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. Wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on steep shady slopes. The old snowpack will be quite stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow as well as the mostly small wind slabs will be deposited on a weakly bonded old snowpack above approximately 1700 m. The avalanche prone locations are to be found on steep shady slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. New snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. The fresh snow and the wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack. In particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The weather conditions on Thursday gave rise to moistening of the old snowpack. In the regions exposed to rain this applies in particular at intermediate and high altitudes. Below approximately 1000 m a little snow is lying. The new snow and wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack.
